0.user_question: James wants to hang crepe-paper streamers from his backyard fence for his birthday party. His backyard fence is a rectangle that measures 20 feet on the long side and 15 feet on the short side. How many feet of crepe paper does James need to buy?

direct_answer.text: To find out the length around the rectangular area (perimeter), we add up all sides like this : P=L+W+L+W or simply as  2*(length + width). Let’s plug our values into formula. It becomes -> P = 2* (20ft + 15 ft) which simplifies down to ->P = 2* (35ft) , hence finally-> P = 70ft . Therefore, James needs to purchase 70 feet of crepe-paper streamers. The answer is: 70.

0.user_question: James wants to hang crepe-paper streamers from his backyard fence for his birthday party. His backyard fence is a rectangle that measures 20 feet on the long side and 15 feet on the short side. How many feet of crepe paper does James need to buy?

ost_step.1: Calculate one length along the edge of the rectangular area (either 20 or 15). Let's choose the longer dimension which would require less string per run; therefore we use Length=20feet.
ost_step.2: Multiply this value times two since it’ll take up both sides around all four corners(each corner needs a new piece), so you get Total_length =  2*Length = 2 * 20ft = <<2*20=40>>40 ft.
ost_step.3: To determine if any excess may exist depending upon your placement, subtract halfway across width as well because at every turn point when wrapping over/under each strand requires additional material also known as overlap factor=(Width /2 ) . For example : here Width = 15 , thus Overlap Factor becomes Half of Width i.e., Overlap_Factor = 15/2 => Overflow_factor = <<15/2=7.5>>7.5 ft approximately considering round off errors. It takes extra amount equivalent to height above mentioned while going under another layer hence added into calculation lateral steps taken around entire border including top & bottom edges too making them partake fully in overall requirement calculations thereby increasing needed lengths beyond simple linear measurement alone..

0.user_question: James wants to hang crepe-paper streamers from his backyard fence for his birthday party. His backyard fence is a rectangle that measures 20 feet on the long side and 15 feet on the short side. How many feet of crepe paper does James need to buy?

direct_answer.text: To find out the length around the rectangular area (perimeter), we add up all sides like this : P=L+W+L+W or simply as  2*(length + width). Let’s plug our values into formula. It becomes -> P = 2* (20ft + 15 ft) which simplifies down to ->P = 2* (35ft) , hence finally-> P = 70ft . Therefore, James needs to purchase 70 feet of crepe-paper streamers. The answer is: 70.

0.user_question: James wants to hang crepe-paper streamers from his backyard fence for his birthday party. His backyard fence is a rectangle that measures 20 feet on the long side and 15 feet on the short side. How many feet of crepe paper does James need to buy?

direct_answer.text: To find out the length around the rectangular area (perimeter), we add up all sides like this : P=L+W+L+W or simply as  2*(length + width). Let’s plug our values into formula. It becomes -> P = 2* (20ft + 15 ft) which simplifies down to ->P = 2* (35ft) , hence finally-> P = 70ft . Therefore, James needs to purchase 70 feet of crepe-paper streamers. The answer is: 70.

1.subquestion: To find out how many feet of crepe paper streams James needs to purchase, let us first calculate the perimeter (P) of his rectangular backyard using its length (L=20ft) and width (W=15ft). The formula P=2(L+W) will give us what we need.

subanswer.text: By substituting L=20ft and W=15ft into our equation;

ost_step.1: We find P=(L+W)×2=(20 ft+15 ft) × 2=70 ft (total length required).

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step using the hint provided. Firstly we add up the lengths of all sides which would form one complete cycle around the rectangular area i.e., Length(L)+Width(W), this equals to 20ft+(shortside)=20ft+15ft=35ft per single round trip along edges. Since it’s a rectangle, so basically doing these steps twice covers entire outer edge as if you drew lines starting & ending at corners like clock hand movement through whole time frame; thus ,two trips means covering four times original sum hence multiply resultant value again once .i.e..P=(Length+width)*2=(20ft+15ft)(2)=35ft*2=70ft Finally double counting makes sure no corner missed out or overlooked when hanging across poles!
